description: A large berry containing a single large seed. It has a creamy texture and rich, buttery flavor. Known for its healthy fats.
seasons: Varies by variety and region; often year-round availability due to global sourcing
healthBenefits: Rich in monounsaturated fats, particularly oleic acid, beneficial for heart health.
High in fiber, aiding digestion and promoting satiety.
Excellent source of potassium, which helps regulate blood pressure.
Contains various vitamins and antioxidants that support overall health.

potentialAllergies.name: Latex-Fruit Syndrome
potentialAllergies.details: Individuals allergic to latex may also react to avocados.

potentialAllergies.name: Avocado Allergy
potentialAllergies.details: True avocado allergy is rare but can cause oral allergy symptoms or more severe reactions.

cultivationProcess:
Step-by-Step Growing Guide:
1. Climate: Subtropical to tropical. Different varieties have different cold tolerances.
2. Soil: Well-drained, aerated soil with a pH of 6.0-7.0. Avoid heavy clay soils.
3. Propagation: Usually by grafting onto rootstock. Growing from seed is possible but fruit quality is unpredictable and takes longer.
4. Planting: Plant in full sun, protected from strong winds.
5. Watering: Regular, deep watering, especially for young trees and during fruit development. Allow soil to dry slightly between waterings.
6. Fertilizing: Apply balanced citrus/avocado fertilizer several times a year.
7. Harvesting: Avocados do not ripen on the tree. They are harvested when mature (size and oil content) and then ripen at room temperature. Maturity signs vary by variety.
growthDuration: Grafted trees can start bearing fruit in 3-5 years. Fruits take 6-18 months to mature on the tree, depending on variety.
sustainabilityTips: Store unripe avocados at room temperature; ripened ones in the refrigerator.
To speed up ripening, place in a paper bag with an apple or banana.
Use lemon/lime juice on cut avocado to prevent browning.
Consider water usage in avocado production; choose sources with sustainable water practices if possible.
carbonFootprintInfo: Can be high due to water requirements and transportation (0.8-2.5 kg CO2e/kg).

staticRecipes.name: Classic Guacamole
staticRecipes.description: A staple Mexican dip made from mashed avocados, lime juice, onions, cilantro, and seasonings.
steps: Cut avocados in half, remove pits, and scoop flesh into a medium bowl.
Mash the avocado with a fork to desired consistency (chunky or smooth).
Add chopped onion, minced jalapeño/serrano (if using), cilantro, and lime juice. Stir to combine.
Season with salt to taste. If using tomatoes, gently fold them in.
Serve immediately with tortilla chips or as a topping.

staticRecipes.name: Avocado Toast
staticRecipes.description: A simple and popular breakfast or snack.
ingredients: 2 slices of your favorite bread, toasted
Optional toppings: Red pepper flakes, everything bagel seasoning, a drizzle of olive oil, a squeeze of lemon juice, a fried egg
steps: Toast bread slices to desired crispness.
Mash avocado in a small bowl with a fork. Season with salt and pepper (and lemon juice if using).
Spread the mashed avocado evenly over the toasted bread.
Add any desired toppings. Serve immediately.

staticRecipes.name: Avocado Chocolate Mousse
staticRecipes.description: A surprisingly delicious and healthy dessert that's rich and creamy.
ingredients: 1/4 cup maple syrup or honey (or to taste)
1/4 cup almond milk or other non-dairy milk
steps: Combine avocado flesh, cocoa powder, maple syrup/honey, almond milk, vanilla extract, and salt in a food processor or high-speed blender.
Blend until completely smooth and creamy, scraping down the sides as needed.
Taste and adjust sweetness if necessary.
Divide into small serving dishes and chill in the refrigerator for at least 30 minutes to an hour to firm up.
Serve chilled. Can be topped with berries or chocolate shavings.
